title: John Holmes (rugby league)
text:
John Holmes (21 March 1952 – 26 September 2009) was an English <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> winning professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played as a and forward in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s.
He played at representative level for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>, as a for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> and <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Yorkshire</a>, and at club level for <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a>.
Background.
John Holmes was born in <a href="Kirkstall">Kirkstall</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, England, and he died aged 57 in <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a>, <a href="West%20Yorkshire">West Yorkshire</a>, England.
International honours.
John Holmes won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> while at Leeds in the <a href="1975%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1975 Rugby League World Cup</a> against Wales, France, New Zealand, and Australia, in 1977 against Wales, and France (sub), in 1978 against France (sub), and won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Leeds in 1971 against New Zealand, in 1972 against France (2 matches), in the <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1972 Rugby League World Cup</a> against Australia (sub), New Zealand and Australia, in the <a href="1977%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1977 Rugby League World Cup</a> against France, New Zealand, Australia, and Australia (sub), in 1978 against Australia (sub) (3 matches), in 1979 against Australia (2 matches), Australia (sub), and New Zealand (3 matches), and in 1982 against Australia.
Career at Leeds.
In a career spanning from 1968 to 1990, Holmes made a club record 625 appearances for <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a>, starting his career as a or , and later switching to <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Stand-off">stand-off</a>. His début was in a <a href="Harry%20Jepson%20OBE%20Memorial%20Cup">Lazenby Cup</a> match against <a href="Hunslet%20R.L.F.C.">Hunslet</a> where he scored a try and kicked 10 goals. Holmes played in nineteen major finals for <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> winning all but five. He played at the highest level representing Yorkshire, <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> and <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>. He made 20 appearances between 1971 and 1982 for Great Britain, and was a <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> winner for Great Britain in 1972 at the age of twenty.
John Holmes played in <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds'</a> 26–11 victory over <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Rugby%20League%20Premiership%20Final">1974–75</a> <a href="Rugby%20League%20Premiership">Premiership</a> Final during the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1974–75 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 17 May 1975, but missed the 24–2 victory over <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Northern</a> in the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Rugby%20League%20Premiership%20Final">1978-9</a> <a href="Rugby%20League%20Premiership">Premiership</a> Final during the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1978–79 season</a> at <a href="Fartown%20Ground">Fartown Ground</a>, <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> on Saturday 27 May 1979 after being called up as a late replacement for the 1979 GB Lions Tour to Australasia.
John Holmes played in <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds'</a> 7–24 defeat by <a href="Leigh%20Centurions">Leigh</a> in the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Challenge%20Cup">1970–71</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1970–71 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 15 May 1971, in front of a crowd of 85,514, played in the 13–16 defeat by <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20Challenge%20Cup">1971–72</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1971–72 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 13 May 1972, in front of a crowd of 89,495, played in the 16–7 victory over <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Challenge%20Cup">1976–77</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1976–77 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 7 May 1977, in front of a crowd of 80,871, and played in the 14–12 victory over <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Challenge%20Cup">1977–78</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1977–78 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 13 May 1978, in front of a crowd of 96,000.

John Holmes played , and scored 2-<a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">conversion</a>s in <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a>' 9–5 victory over <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1970%20BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">1970</a> <a href="BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">BBC2 Floodlit Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1970–71 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Tuesday 15 December 1970.
John Holmes played , and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">conversion</a> in <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a>' 12–7 victory over <a href="Salford%20Red%20Devils">Salford</a> in the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1972–73</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">Player's No.6 Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1972–73 season</a> at <a href="Fartown%20Ground">Fartown Ground</a>, <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> on Saturday 24 March 1973, played in the 4–15 defeat by <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> in the <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1982–83</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Player Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1982–83 season</a> at <a href="Elland%20Road">Elland Road</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 22 January 1983, played , and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the 18–10 victory over <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1983%E2%80%9384%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1983–84</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Player Special Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1983%E2%80%9384%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1983–84 season</a> at <a href="Central%20Park%20%28Wigan%29">Central Park</a>, <a href="Wigan">Wigan</a> on Saturday 14 January 1984. 
John Holmes' <a href="testimonial%20match">testimonial match</a> at <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> took place in 1989.
He died from cancer on 27 September 2009. A minute's silence was observed to mark Holmes' death at the Qualifying Semi-final between Leeds and <a href="Catalan%20Dragons">Catalan Dragons</a> on the 4th of October 2009. On 10 October, Leeds won the <a href="2009%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">Super League Grand Final</a>, captain <a href="Kevin%20Sinfield">Kevin Sinfield</a> dedicated the victory to Holmes.
